evidence_items.text: Two members of the syndicate that owned the aircraft drove to Enstone Airfield together on the morning of the accident. They arrived at approximately 1000 hrs and moved the aircraft out of its hangar. The surviving syndicate member described the pre-flight checks as “all good.” That pilot boarded the aircraft and taxied out at approximately 1200 hrs. He conducted a general handling flight in the local area for 30 minutes, during which there were no technical issues with the aircraft. He parked the aircraft near point B for the crew change.
The initial part of the takeoff roll seemed normal and the aircraft tailwheel lifted as expected.

The tail then lowered to the ground and the aircraft yawed left towards the edge of the tarmac runway. As it approached the edge of the tarmac, the aircraft pitched up sharply and then rolled rapidly to the left. The left wingtip struck the ground, with approximately 120 ° of bank angle, followed by the nose. Immediately after the nose struck the ground a large fire broke out causing extensive further damage to the aircraft. The pilot was fatally injured.
A recording of the radio communications between the pilot and airfield radio operator was also available.
Other potential sources of data, such as the pilot’s mobile phone and the aircraft’s MoTeC SDL3 instrument logger fitted in the cockpit were destroyed in the fire.

Aircraft at start of takeoff run When the aircraft’s airspeed reached approximately 45 kt, the tail of the aircraft lifted to an almost horizontal attitude, which coincided with a brief left rudder input, and the aircraft yawed to the left. The elevator could then be observed to move to a pitch up (control surface up) position, which was near to its full travel position, and the tail of the aircraft quickly lowered back towards the runway. The elevator remained in a pitch-up position, whilst the tailwheel tyre bounced on and off the runway surface several times. The aircraft’s weight then settled on the tail wheel, which was almost coincident with the main landing gear tyres leaving the runway surface.

The aircraft continued to head towards the left side of the runway with the main wheels just clear of the runway surface whilst the tailwheel remained in contact. The aircraft’s pitch attitude was about 12 ᵒ nose-up. As the aircraft reached the side of the runway its airspeed was approximately 63 kt and it pitched up quickly at a rate of about 12ᵒ/s and started to climb. The elevators could then be seen to move quickly to a more neutral position. The pitch attitude reached just over 20ᵒ and the data indicated that the aircraft’s airspeed reduced to approximately 58 kt. The aircraft then started rolling left, with a slight reduction in its pitch attitude to about 18ᵒ nose-up.

The aircraft’s ailerons were then observed to move to a right roll position (left aileron surface down / right aileron surface up) but the aircraft continued rolling left. The footage of the aircraft captured by the witness ended shortly after this point but the continuing flight path of the aircraft was recorded by one of the CCTV cameras. When the aircraft’s bank angle reached about 30 ᵒ, its pitch attitude briefly stabilised at about 15 ᵒ nose-up but as the bank angle reached about 40 ᵒ the roll rate increased quickly to about 70ᵒ/s. The aircraft’s nose started to drop and the aircraft descended, with the bank angle reaching about 120ᵒ before the aircraft struck the ground, left wingtip first, at 1257:40 hrs.

The time interval from the start of the takeoff run to the aircraft striking the ground was about 17 seconds with the aircraft reaching a maximum height of approximately 30 ft agl. The rudder, elevators and ailerons could all be seen to have been moving during periods of the video footage and both flaps appeared symmetrically deployed.

Engine and propellor speed The mobile phone recording contained sounds consistent with the operation of the aircraft’s engine. This showed that at the start of the takeoff run the engine speed was about 2,000 rpm, and that the engine rpm was then progressively increased to a maximum of about 4,300 rpm; this equated to a propellor speed 2 of about 2,360 rpm. The recording indicated that this engine speed was maintained as the aircraft took off through to the aircraft subsequently striking the ground. There was no audible evidence of a problem with the engine, such as it backfiring.
Separate analysis using photogrammetry was also consistent with the propellor speed of about 2,360 rpm.

The previous videos of G-ENAA also showed a more gradual pitch up rotation at liftoff and lower pitch attitudes. Videos of other Mk 26B Spitfires also showed a similar tail-up takeoff technique, rotation rates and pitch attitudes.
Shows the difference between G-ENAA’s pitch attitude during the accident takeoff and that in December 2017, and shows the difference in the initial climb attitudes adopted.

An electric motor operated by a switch in the cockpit, drives a common torque tube to move the flaps. There are no specific flap detents, but white marker lines painted on the inboard edge of the right aileron allow the pilot to judge flap position.
A trim tab on the right elevator is operated by a lever and Bowden cable 4 mechanism.

The rudder control system consists of steel cables running from the rudder along the left and right side of the fuselage to the rudder pedals in the cockpit. A second cable runs forward from the rudder pedals, to form a continuous cable loop. This cable includes a turnbuckle at its midpoint and is routed through two pulleys on the left and right side of the footwell. The pulleys are mounted on a steel plate, on the aft face of the firewall. The rudder pedal position can be adjusted fore and aft in one of seven positions, but this can only be accomplished on the ground.

The pilot’s seat has three positions to allow fore and aft adjustment of the seat on the ground by means of a pip-pin. A four-point harness, incorporating a quick release fitting (QRF) was fitted, with the shoulder straps attached to the rear cockpit bulkhead. G-ENAA had provision for a second seat behind the pilot, and this was also equipped with a four-point harness.

G-ENAA was powered by an Isuzu V6 fuel injected, normally aspirated, piston engine driving a three-blade variable pitch propeller. It was equipped with an electrically operated main landing gear and a fixed tail wheel and had a maximum takeoff weight of 860 kg.

An electrical stall warning tab was fitted to the right wing. In addition to modern analogue instruments, the cockpit instrument panel was equipped with several avionic devices including a digital MoTec SDL3 engine and electrical power monitoring display, and digital radio and transponder.

Aircraft information G-ENAA was built and based at Enstone Airfield. The aircraft was constructed during 2013 and 2014 by a small team which included the accident pilot. This was followed by a period of test flying between October 2014 and March 2016. Since then, the aircraft had operated on an LAA Permit to Fly, for which the most recent certificate of validity was issued on 8 July 2024.
At the time of the accident G-ENAA was one of three Mk 26B’s on the UK register.
Another Mk 26B, G-CLHJ, was previously destroyed in a fatal accident near Enstone on 22 August 2023.

Aircraft Handling Notes After it was built, the aircraft was flown by an LAA test pilot who made the following comments in his written report: ‘a. The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

B. On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

C. Though the manufacturer indicated a CG envelope of 600 to 875 mm aft of datum, the aircraft was found to be longitudinally unstable at CG position 849 mm aft of datum. A limit of 745 mm aft of datum was suggested.
D. In the aft CG condition, stick force per g gradient was found to be low so care was advised to avoid exceeding maximum g.

E. Initially a marked left wing drop (> 60°) at the stall was exhibited in all configurations. Stall strips were fitted to the inboard leading edge of the wing which resulted in satisfactory stalling qualities.
F. There was an audio stall warner fitted which activated 5 to 10 kt prior to all stalls. There was little or no buffet and no tendency to spin.
G. The stalling speed wings level, with idle power was 48 kt flaps up and 43 kt with 10° of flap.
H. In a 30° banked left turn at 75% power the stalling speed flaps up was 50 kt and with 10° flap 44 kt.
In the accident video it appeared that the elevator trim tab was set to approximately its mid-travel nose-up trim condition for the takeoff.
Post Stall Autorotation When an aircraft rolls, the relative airflow (RAF) over each wing is formed from components of forward speed and roll as shown in.

General The aircraft had suffered substantial impact damage, forcing the engine into the cockpit space. The intense post-crash fire was focused on the cockpit and centre section of aircraft and the majority of components in this area were totally consumed or rendered unrecognisable. The main spar had broken just outboard of the transportation joint, such that the left wing was completely detached from the aircraft. The main landing gear legs remained attached to the spar and were extended.

All but the outer third of the left wing had been consumed by the fire and the remainder had suffered extensive fire damage. Nothing remained of the stall warning system that could be tested. The right wing was intact and did not sustain any fire damage. The right wingtip was bent and the damage consistent with it having struck the ground as the aircraft was inverted. There was evidence that a stall strip had been glued to the right wing leading edge but it was not present and may have been dislodged in the impact.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple historical evidence items (H1, H6, H7, H9, H10, H11, H20) confirm the aircraft was available and operational within the specified scope, with pre-flight checks described as 'all good', successful handling flight with no technical issues, and engine operation confirmed by recordings.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence directly confirms availability

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H3, H6-H9, H33) directly describes the aircraft's failure during takeoff leading to loss of control, crash, and fire, indicating unexpected operational interruption and downtime, thus affecting availability.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple historical evidence items (H1, H2, H6-H11) describe the aircraft's normal pre-flight checks, taxi, takeoff roll, control surface movements, and engine operation, indicating environmental or weather factors were available and observable in the context.

quotes.exact_quote: Two members of the syndicate that owned the aircraft drove to Enstone Airfield together on the morning of the accident. They arrived at approximately 1000 hrs and moved the aircraft out of its hangar. The surviving syndicate member described the pre-flight checks as 1all good.2 That pilot boarded the aircraft and taxied out at approximately 1200 hrs. He conducted a general handling flight in the local area for 30 minutes, during which there were no technical issues with the aircraft.

G-ENAA was built and based at Enstone Airfield. The aircraft was constructed during 2013 and 2014 by a small team which included the accident pilot. This was followed by a period of test flying between October 2014 and March 2016. Since then, the aircraft had operated on an LAA Permit to Fly, for which the most recent certificate of validity was issued on 8 July 2024.

Aircraft Handling Notes After it was built, the aircraft was flown by an LAA test pilot who made the following comments in his written report: a. The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

B. On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1 and H20 confirm the aircraft was operational and available for flight with valid certification and no technical issues during pre-flight and handling flights. H23 and H24 provide handling notes indicating the aircraft was controllable and had adequate rudder control after adjustment, supporting availability of ground handling and airport interface.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement about ground handling or airport interface availability; inference based on operational flight and handling data

node.statement: H_flight_handling_loss_of_control fits the key features required for Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim.

defeaters: If evidence showed significant deviations in handling characteristics from the Mk 26B standard or unaddressed control deficiencies.
If the accident flight handling was atypical compared to other flights or aircraft of the same model.

quotes.exact_quote: After it was built, the aircraft was flown by an LAA test pilot who made the following comments: 'a. The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.'

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

Though the manufacturer indicated a CG envelope of 600 to 875 mm aft of datum, the aircraft was found to be longitudinally unstable at CG position 849 mm aft of datum. A limit of 745 mm aft of datum was suggested.
In the aft CG condition, stick force per g gradient was found to be low so care was advised to avoid exceeding maximum g.

Initially a marked left wing drop (> 60°) at the stall was exhibited in all configurations. Stall strips were fitted to the inboard leading edge of the wing which resulted in satisfactory stalling qualities.
There was an audio stall warner fitted which activated 5 to 10 kt prior to all stalls. There was little or no buffet and no tendency to spin.
The stalling speed wings level, with idle power was 48 kt flaps up and 43 kt with 10° of flap.
In a 30° banked left turn at 75% power the stalling speed flaps up was 50 kt and with 10° flap 44 kt.
In the accident video it appeared that the elevator trim tab was set to approximately its mid-travel nose-up trim condition for the takeoff.

The previous videos of G-ENAA also showed a more gradual pitch up rotation at liftoff and lower pitch attitudes. Videos of other Mk 26B Spitfires also showed a similar tail-up takeoff technique, rotation rates and pitch attitudes.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence from test pilot reports (H23-H26) and handling notes (H27-H30) directly describe the aircraft's handling characteristics, including takeoff behavior, rudder effectiveness, CG stability, stall behavior, and trim settings (H31). Video comparisons (H12) confirm typical handling consistent with the Spitfire Mk 26B. This supports that H_flight_handling_loss_of_control fits the key features required for the specified scope.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains due to limited direct flight data from the accident flight and destruction of some instrumentation (H5), but test pilot and historical data mitigate this.

node.statement: The system or component failure aligns with key features observed in Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim, such as specific failure modes and their impact on system performance.

assumptions: The historical observations and pilot reports accurately reflect the failure modes
No other unreported mechanical failures contributed to the accident
defeaters: Additional technical data showing a different failure mode or mechanical malfunction not observed in the history
Evidence that the aircraft was properly trimmed and within CG limits at the time of failure
Data from destroyed instruments that could clarify control inputs or mechanical failures

quotes.exact_quote: When the aircraft’s airspeed reached approximately 45 kt, the tail of the aircraft lifted to an almost horizontal attitude, which coincided with a brief left rudder input, and the aircraft yawed to the left. The elevator could then be observed to move to a pitch up (control surface up) position, which was near to its full travel position, and the tail of the aircraft quickly lowered back towards the runway.

The aircraft continued to head towards the left side of the runway with the main wheels just clear of the runway surface whilst the tailwheel remained in contact. The aircraft’s pitch attitude was about 12 ° nose-up. As the aircraft reached the side of the runway its airspeed was approximately 63 kt and it pitched up quickly at a rate of about 12°/s and started to climb. The elevators could then be seen to move quickly to a more neutral position. The pitch attitude reached just over 20° and the data indicated that the aircraft’s airspeed reduced to approximately 58 kt. The aircraft then started rolling left, with a slight reduction in its pitch attitude to about 18° nose-up.

The aircraft’s ailerons were then observed to move to a right roll position (left aileron surface down / right aileron surface up) but the aircraft continued rolling left. The footage of the aircraft captured by the witness ended shortly after this point but the continuing flight path of the aircraft was recorded by one of the CCTV cameras. When the aircraft’s bank angle reached about 30 °, its pitch attitude briefly stabilised at about 15 ° nose-up but as the bank angle reached about 40 ° the roll rate increased quickly to about 70°/s. The aircraft’s nose started to drop and the aircraft descended, with the bank angle reaching about 120° before the aircraft struck the ground, left wingtip first, at 1257:40 hrs.
The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

Though the manufacturer indicated a CG envelope of 600 to 875 mm aft of datum, the aircraft was found to be longitudinally unstable at CG position 849 mm aft of datum. A limit of 745 mm aft of datum was suggested.
In the aft CG condition, stick force per g gradient was found to be low so care was advised to avoid exceeding maximum g.

Initially a marked left wing drop (> 60°) at the stall was exhibited in all configurations. Stall strips were fitted to the inboard leading edge of the wing which resulted in satisfactory stalling qualities.
In the accident video it appeared that the elevator trim tab was set to approximately its mid-travel nose-up trim condition for the takeoff.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence (H6-H8) directly describes the failure modes observed during takeoff, including yawing left, rapid pitch up, roll left, and loss of control consistent with known handling characteristics and instability issues (H23-H27). The elevator trim setting (H31) and rudder control limitations (H24) further support alignment with key failure features.

node.statement: H_ground_handling_or_airport_interface fits the key features required for Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: The documented handling notes and test pilot reports accurately represent the aircraft's handling characteristics
The aircraft configuration at the time of the accident was consistent with the standard Mk 26B features
defeaters: If evidence showed the aircraft had modifications or handling characteristics significantly different from the standard Mk 26B
If pre-flight checks or handling flights revealed unresolved technical issues
If the aircraft's CG or control systems were outside recommended limits affecting handling

quotes.exact_quote: The surviving syndicate member described the pre-flight checks as 1 all good.2 He conducted a general handling flight in the local area for 30 minutes, during which there were no technical issues with the aircraft.
The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

Though the manufacturer indicated a CG envelope of 600 to 875 mm aft of datum, the aircraft was found to be longitudinally unstable at CG position 849 mm aft of datum. A limit of 745 mm aft of datum was suggested.
In the aft CG condition, stick force per g gradient was found to be low so care was advised to avoid exceeding maximum g.

Initially a marked left wing drop (> 606) at the stall was exhibited in all configurations. Stall strips were fitted to the inboard leading edge of the wing which resulted in satisfactory stalling qualities.
There was an audio stall warner fitted which activated 5 to 10 kt prior to all stalls. There was little or no buffet and no tendency to spin.
The stalling speed wings level, with idle power was 48 kt flaps up and 43 kt with 106 of flap.
In a 306 banked left turn at 75% power the stalling speed flaps up was 50 kt and with 106 flap 44 kt.
In the accident video it appeared that the elevator trim tab was set to approximately its mid-travel nose-up trim condition for the takeoff.
Videos of other Mk 26B Spitfires also showed a similar tail-up takeoff technique, rotation rates and pitch attitudes.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows that the aircraft underwent pre-flight checks with no technical issues (H1), had handling characteristics consistent with the Mk 26B type including known left swing on takeoff and rudder adjustments (H23, H24), and that the aircraft's handling and stall characteristics were documented and consistent with the key features of the Spitfire Mk 26B (H25-H31). Videos of other Mk 26B Spitfires confirm similar handling (H12).
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity remains due to limited data from destroyed instruments and lack of detailed comparison of all key features, but overall evidence supports fit to key features.

node.statement: H_flight_handling_loss_of_control demonstrates defeater resistance in the scope of Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Defeater resistance implies the aircraft and pilot could maintain or regain control despite destabilizing factors
Control surface movements observed indicate pilot attempts to counteract loss of control
defeaters: Direct evidence of pilot control inputs successfully countering the left roll and yaw during the accident sequence
Data showing the aircraft maintained stable flight attitudes despite disturbances
Evidence of mechanical or control system failures that would negate defeater resistance

quotes.exact_quote: He conducted a general handling flight in the local area for 30 minutes, during which there were no technical issues with the aircraft.

When the aircraft’s airspeed reached approximately 45 kt, the tail of the aircraft lifted to an almost horizontal attitude, which coincided with a brief left rudder input, and the aircraft yawed to the left. The elevator could then be observed to move to a pitch up (control surface up) position, which was near to its full travel position, and the tail of the aircraft quickly lowered back towards the runway.

The aircraft continued to head towards the left side of the runway with the main wheels just clear of the runway surface whilst the tailwheel remained in contact. The aircraft’s pitch attitude was about 12 ° nose-up. As the aircraft reached the side of the runway its airspeed was approximately 63 kt and it pitched up quickly at a rate of about 12°/s and started to climb. The elevators could then be seen to move quickly to a more neutral position.
The aircraft’s ailerons were then observed to move to a right roll position (left aileron surface down / right aileron surface up) but the aircraft continued rolling left.
The rudder, elevators and ailerons could all be seen to have been moving during periods of the video footage and both flaps appeared symmetrically deployed.
The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows the aircraft exhibited significant left yaw and roll tendencies during takeoff despite control surface inputs (H6, H7, H8, H9). Prior test flights noted difficulty containing left swing even with full rudder (H23, H24). However, the aircraft was controllable with adjusted rudder deflection, and control surfaces were active during the accident sequence, indicating some resistance to loss of control defeaters. No direct evidence shows complete loss of control or inability to resist defeaters.

node.statement: H_ground_handling_or_airport_interface demonstrates defeater resistance within the context of Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim.

assumptions: Defeater resistance implies ability to maintain control despite adverse conditions or unexpected events during ground handling or airport interface
defeaters: Direct evidence of pilot or ground handling interventions successfully countering unexpected events
Data showing robust control system performance preventing loss of control

quotes.exact_quote: The surviving syndicate member described the pre-flight checks as 1 all good.2

When the aircrafts airspeed reached approximately 45 kt, the tail of the aircraft lifted to an almost horizontal attitude, which coincided with a brief left rudder input, and the aircraft yawed to the left. The elevator could then be observed to move to a pitch up (control surface up) position, which was near to its full travel position, and the tail of the aircraft quickly lowered back towards the runway.

The aircraft continued to head towards the left side of the runway with the main wheels just clear of the runway surface whilst the tailwheel remained in contact. The aircrafts pitch attitude was about 12 52 nose-up. As the aircraft reached the side of the runway its airspeed was approximately 63 kt and it pitched up quickly at a rate of about 1252/s and started to climb. The elevators could then be seen to move quickly to a more neutral position.
The aircrafts ailerons were then observed to move to a right roll position (left aileron surface down / right aileron surface up) but the aircraft continued rolling left.
The rudder, elevators and ailerons could all be seen to have been moving during periods of the video footage and both flaps appeared symmetrically deployed.
The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence shows pre-flight checks were good (H1) and control surfaces were responsive during takeoff (H6, H7, H8, H9). However, the aircraft exhibited a marked left swing difficult to contain even with full rudder (H23, H24), indicating limited resistance to defeaters in ground handling or airport interface.

node.statement: The system or component failure demonstrates limited defeater resistance in Spitfire_MK_26B_G-ENAA_01-26:hist_t2_interim, indicating vulnerabilities to certain failure triggers or environmental conditions.

assumptions: The observed handling difficulties imply limited defeater resistance
The accident flight behavior reflects inherent aircraft vulnerabilities rather than pilot error alone
defeaters: Evidence of robust control and stability preventing loss of control despite adverse conditions
Data showing no history of instability or control issues in similar conditions
Evidence of mechanical failure unrelated to defeater resistance

quotes.exact_quote: The takeoff was spritely with rapid acceleration. The tail was lifted at 50 kt and a marked swing to the left was experienced.

On earlier flights this swing could hardly be contained even with full application of right rudder. Full rudder deflection was found to be less than the factory recommendation but, following adjustment, the rudder deflection was adequate to retain directional control.

Though the manufacturer indicated a CG envelope of 600 to 875 mm aft of datum, the aircraft was found to be longitudinally unstable at CG position 849 mm aft of datum. A limit of 745 mm aft of datum was suggested.

When the aircraft’s airspeed reached approximately 45 kt, the tail of the aircraft lifted to an almost horizontal attitude, which coincided with a brief left rudder input, and the aircraft yawed to the left. The elevator could then be observed to move to a pitch up (control surface up) position, which was near to its full travel position, and the tail of the aircraft quickly lowered back towards the runway.

The aircraft continued to head towards the left side of the runway with the main wheels just clear of the runway surface whilst the tailwheel remained in contact. The aircraft’s pitch attitude was about 12 ° nose-up. As the aircraft reached the side of the runway its airspeed was approximately 63 kt and it pitched up quickly at a rate of about 12°/s and started to climb. The elevators could then be seen to move quickly to a more neutral position. The pitch attitude reached just over 20° and the data indicated that the aircraft’s airspeed reduced to approximately 58 kt. The aircraft then started rolling left, with a slight reduction in its pitch attitude to about 18° nose-up.

The aircraft’s ailerons were then observed to move to a right roll position (left aileron surface down / right aileron surface up) but the aircraft continued rolling left. The footage of the aircraft captured by the witness ended shortly after this point but the continuing flight path of the aircraft was recorded by one of the CCTV cameras. When the aircraft’s bank angle reached about 30 °, its pitch attitude briefly stabilised at about 15 ° nose-up but as the bank angle reached about 40 ° the roll rate increased quickly to about 70°/s. The aircraft’s nose started to drop and the aircraft descended, with the bank angle reaching about 120° before the aircraft struck the ground, left wingtip first, at 1257:40 hrs.

The tail then lowered to the ground and the aircraft yawed left towards the edge of the tarmac runway. As it approached the edge of the tarmac, the aircraft pitched up sharply and then rolled rapidly to the left. The left wingtip struck the ground, with approximately 120 ° of bank angle, followed by the nose. Immediately after the nose struck the ground a large fire broke out causing extensive further damage to the aircraft. The pilot was fatally injured.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H23, H24, H25) shows known handling difficulties including marked left swing and longitudinal instability, indicating limited defeater resistance. The accident sequence (H6-H8, H3) demonstrates loss of control despite control surface inputs, consistent with vulnerabilities to failure triggers or environmental conditions.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Lack of direct mechanical failure data and destroyed instrumentation limits full understanding of failure triggers
